Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the Koo test to assess residency under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of their time in Canada due to business-related absences
Crimes.Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was unreasonable
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada justified by business needs
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory physical presence requirement
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Application of the Koo test for qualitative assessment of residency
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Records of physical presence, business activities abroad
Crimes.Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of absences, nature of business ties abroad
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Quashing of approval and referral for re-determination
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Koo test for assessing residency when physical presence is insufficient
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence demonstrating strong residential ties to Canada
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed; matter referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Cause_Description: Respondents applied for citizenship despite significant time spent abroad for business
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court found inadequate consideration of Koo criteria
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Overreliance on business justifications over residential connections
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient weight given to physical presence and residential ties
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge substituted business necessity for required residential connection
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to properly evaluate all six Koo factors

Crimes.Violation_Type: False or misleading representation regarding residency
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the respondents met the residency requirements under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of their time in Canada; four of six Koo factors did not support Canadian residency
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Re-determination by a different Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Decision was unreasonable due to improper application of the Koo test
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Maintained primary residence and operations abroad while claiming Canadian residency
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Significant shortfall in physical presence and weak residential ties
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Strength of residential, economic, and familial ties to Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister’s appeal of Citizenship Judge’s decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Implied lack of credibility in asserting residency
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel records, business operations, property ownership, family location
Crimes.Application_Basis: Requirement to accumulate 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Extent of physical presence and qualitative residential connections
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Koo test for evaluating residency in absence of full physical presence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate meaningful residential ties to Canada
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal granted; matter remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper conferral of citizenship
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applications approved despite clear deficiencies in residency compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Inadequate evaluation of Koo criteria by original judge
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Disregard of objective indicators of non-residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes – implied false assertion of residency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge failed to apply Koo test properly and overemphasized business activities
